title: Turnover is not made of apples
body: for various reasons  i've quit on a bunch of horrible employers over the past year  but usually only when i had money saved up and or something else lined up that i could do afterward      here's what i found after being on their contact lists for so long       -wis international sent an invitation for me to come back twice  i've quit on them in consecutive years  and they still sent me something wanting me back because they can't find enough staff for their business  this is the company that has practices which are  well highly illegal  such as forcing hotel stays where employees only get four hours of sleep  forcing people to work 16 to 24 hours in a row  things like that  they've had three or four managerial shakesup since i've been on their email list  and nothing ever really seems to change       -pratt-whitney is a horrible warehouse chain that uses ups for their warehouse operations in a town called londonderry  i worked there for six months last year and  surprisingly  it's one of the better jobs i had  this was the job that made me suicidal and feel hopeless about life  they hired a new operations director while i was there  and put in a new staffing coordinator- probably because the ladies who had been doing it up until that point had not been having a good time  this was another job with extremely high turnover to the point where they had a new orientation group in every week  which was highly demoralizing  recently  i got an email saying that they are hiring again  and could i please apply       -callogix was a terrible company that i worked for  and they let me go for various reasons- at 8 in the morning  knowing full well that i would have to sit and wait over three hours for the next bus to come by so i could go home  every now and then  when i pop on indeed to see what's available  i see that they are hiring  this happens about every two months or so  they just can't keep people working for them  their turnover is incredible  and not good like the ones made from apples  more like bad  as in it's appallingly obvious there's an upper class and a lower class at work  these two classes were separated by a locked door with keycard entry      i wonder at what point will managers realize they are costing themselves money by being terrible  i wonder at what point will business owners finally wise up and stop the fast revolving door of entry-level employees and the slowly revolving door of mid-level management  i kind of think it might never actually happen  not as long as employees have to prostrate title: What do you think of Basecamp's work culture?
body: some bits that stand out to me    gt  we value a calm company and deliberate  concerted effort  you ll have a lot fewer meetings  a lot less email  and a lot less interruption  turns out 8 hours are plenty of time to get work done when you don t slice your day into tiny  work moments    gt  every three years  employees are eligible to take a one-month-long paid sabbatical    gt  40 hour work week - work is a marathon  not a sprint  we regularly stick to 40 hours a week  with the occasional emergency or once-every-few-years special push demanding more    gt  32 hour  4-day  summer work week - may 1 through august 31  we work 4 days a week  for a total of 32-hour weeks    gt  whatever hardware  software  or services you need to do your job are always 100  on us  no red tape  no questions asked    gt  paid parental leave - when you welcome a new baby  basecamp encourages you to take up to 16 weeks leave as primary caregiver and up to 6 weeks leave as secondary caregiver  at 100  paid salary  primary or secondary caregivers can choose to take an additional 8 weeks unpaid leave    gt  vacations and paid holidays - basecamp offers 3 weeks of paid vacation  a few extra personal days  and a few national holidays every year  this is a guideline  so don't sweat a few extra days    gt  no office traps - we don't offer things like foosball tables  catered meals in the office  and other  perks  designed to keep you at work for all of your waking hours  we want you to put in 8 quality hours then go live your life  rest  and recharge so you can come back fresh to do it again   what a shame that i don't know of literally any other companies that have a culture like this

title: 21 years of life in a mountain wilderness - I wanted to share this here...
body: from the description      story-line   their home most certainly has a view  ramiz palos and his wife zemina fled the hardships of urban life in bosnia as soon as the country had emerged from a 4-year-war two decades ago    they choose to live on mount vlasic in central bosnia at 1 300 meters above sea level  separated by kilometres of dirt road from the nearest inhabited place    palos says he is not a recluse and was not looking for an escape from traumatic memories  instead  he says  he wanted to take control of his life   after 21 years of primal existence in the wilderness palos feels in control and happy  insisting he would never return to  civilisation    i had several reasons to move here  i came here to secure means for existence  but also to live an exciting life  to not have a boring life  he says    life in the wilderness has many challenges  but palos insists embracing it was easier and more productive than if he had waited for the government to create a job for him    people here  in bosnia  are too willing to surrender responsibility for their own life to somebody else  they are not thinking  people need to think to come up with ways to find work for themselves  i don't have to worry about the work of the government or anyone else  he says   while he sometimes has to fight off bears and wolves and to endure pouring rains  winter storms and strong winds  palos has an abundance of food  fresh air and a warm home    you need to know how to behave  in nature  because we get heavy rains  winter storms and strong winds  you need to know how to behave in such circumstances  he says    sometimes it gets so cold that i cannot leave home for two months  but i have enough food and everything else i need so it does not matter  winter comes and goes   with an unemployment rate of close to 30 percent  finding a job in bosnia can be hard and close to a fifth of the country's population lives in poverty   the country is failing to fully capitalise on the good climatic conditions and an abundance of fertile land that make it one of the most favourable spots for farming in southern europe   but aleksandra nikolic from the sarajevo faculty of agriculture and food science believes that a growing number of bosnians are recognising the advantages of rural life    agriculture is a way of life  it is no longer identified with the image of an exhausted man farming a rough patch of land in the middle of nowhere with the help of emaciated farming animals  she says   agriculture is a sector of economy that helps people in local communities to weather the periods of financial  economic  political or any other crisis by securing a source of income that helps them get through hard times  palos might be the best example of that  when he first moved into the mountains in 1996 he lived in an old van and then in a makeshift tent  but after just a few months  he had built a simple house for himself and was joined by his wife   they still live in the house with no running water and off the electricity grid  but they grow their own vegetables and corn  raise goats and farm fish in the wild mountain river  palos used local wood and stone to build his barn  hatching tanks and the watermill where he grinds his corn   from time to time  palos ventures into the nearest town to sell extra produce to urban dwellers and purchase essential supplies that he and his wife cannot produce for themselves

title: Book recommendations
body: i thought it might be interesting to hear about more books on antiwork than are in the sidebar  what're everyone's favourites and why  the two i think most about are   -the refusal of work by david frayne    this one goes through the ideology of the work ethic  the ways work takes over our lives so even free time isn't really free  and has a lot of interesting and well researched sources  but the thing i really like is it interviews a group of people who've tried to push work out of their lives as much as possible and talks about how they reached a breaking point  one really cathartic part was when they talked about these small slices of utopia they experienced that made them realise something better was possible and they were wasting their life  though it also goes through the social financial pressures that come up when you try to push work out of your life  it opens with a quote from a film called the working class goes to heaven  where antiwork students with megaphones harangue the workers going into a factory in the morning saying  it's 8 o clock in the morning  when you come out it will be dark  the sun will not shine for you today   -bullshit jobs by david graeber  this one's already in the sidebar and is pretty well known  but it talks about one of the most infuriating and frustrating parts of work  a significant portion  if not most  of the work we do is totally pointless  increasing productivity hasn't led to us working less  or freeing us from work entirely  it's led to the proliferation of what're essentially make-work jobs  it goes into how alienating and despairing it can be working those jobs  and why  it proposes a ubi as the solution  though david graeber is an anarchist   put your favorite bits of writing below

title: My boss is micromanaging my time by passive aggresiveness.
